Hi Richard;

There was a tsubako at the San Fran show a couple of years ago=
 from Japan.  He makes great sukashi tsuba.  Price in the 5K to 8K range.  =
He had a number of his tsuba on display, very nice work.

There are people =
in the US and in Japan that can do restoration on iron tsuba, and I have ha=
d some restored in both the US and in Japan.  

I am not certain on kinko a=
s I have never had one done.

John
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: =
Richard Turner 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Wednesday, May =
11, 2005 11:52 PM
  Subject: [nihontostudy] here's probably a really stupid=
 question


  but I have been know to ask plenty of these in my life so why=
 stand on 
  ceremony now :-).

  I was looking at some pitting that is on =
a new tsuba I picked
  ( either Akasaka or Tosa Myochin I think - 
  http:/=
/www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/tsuba/akasaka2.jpg )
  and it has a b=
it more pitting than I thought from the auction images 
  which is a shame.=


  My question for the day then is, if we polish and restore pittings, 
  =
scratches, chips and the likes from swords, is anything like this ever 
  d=
one on iron tsuba ?, I know the obvious thing is the patina but if we 
  ca=
n re patinate nakago, why not tsuba ( at least iron tsuba anyway ) and 
  a=
re there any artisans in Japan presently making tsuba in the old ways 
  an=
d using original patina recipes ?. I know Yoshindo Yoshihara sensei 
  does=
 apparently, and I would love to see some examples of his work. I 
  was th=
inking about this recently, and wondered about the recipes in the 
  back o=
f the Aesthetic Guide and if anyone still does this stuff. If so, 
  could =
very good tsuba with minimal damage be repaired and re patinate 
  and if s=
o, how effectively.

  Right then, foot back in my mouth and over to the ex=
perts.

  cheers

  Rich Turner
